awd_titl_txt: Molecular Mechanisms Employed by TRIM28 to Maintain Epigenetic Information through Different Stages of Embryonic Development
awd_abstract_narration:
How information in genomes is decoded during embryogenesis is one of the greatest mysteries of humankind. Central to this problem is an understanding of how gene expression is regulated. Certain genes are controlled by chemical modifications that are introduced before fertilization. These marks to DNA (also called chromatin marks or genomic imprints) in eggs and sperm are transmitted from parents to children and constitute an important mechanism for the control of gene expression across generations. While research in the last 50 years has uncovered the complexity of chromatin marks, information is still lacking about the factors that recognize and interpret these marks to activate or repress the imprinted genes. Preliminary evidence has revealed a novel role for a specific protein as a regulator of imprinted gene expression. By further defining the requirements for involvement of this protein, this research program will expand fundamental knowledge of the processes and factors that mediate control of gene expression across generations. In addition to enhancing understanding of a fundamental problem in embryonic development, this program of study fosters research by students of all levels. Additionally, both the lead researcher and students participate in several outreach activities to disseminate knowledge of developmental biology. 

Shortly after fertilization, mammalian embryos undergo a genome-wide demethylation event that involves the enzymatic removal of methyl groups from methyl-cytosine DNA residues. The removal of these epigenetic marks allows the reprogramming of the zygotic genome, an essential process for embryogenesis to begin. However, a number of genomic loci, including imprinted genes, need to preserve epigenetic information for the new organism to develop properly. The transcriptional repressor TRIM28 has recently emerged as a key regulator of imprinted gene expression. However, the mechanisms employed by this transcription factor are still unclear. This proposal aims to resolve the requirements of TRIM28 for genomic imprinting at different developmental stages and the molecular mechanisms used by this transcriptional regulator to maintain epigenetic information in developing mouse embryos. Experiments in Specific Aim 1 will analyze the stage-specific requirements of TRIM28 for imprinting control by analyzing the effects of conditional depletion of Trim28 at different times during embryonic development. In Specific Aim 2, the mechanisms by which TRIM28 controls secondary DMR methylation at the Dlk1-Gtl2 locus will be investigated through epistatic analysis. Results from these experiments will provide novel insight not only into the roles of TRIM28, but also into the mechanisms that regulate genomic imprinting.

por.por_cntn:
At fertilization, the genetic material from egg and sperm combine to form a new diploid organism. Its appearance, behavior and abilities will be influenced by  the DNA inherited from the maternal and paternal genomes. For most of our characters, the expression of both the maternal and paternal copies of a gene will contribute to our final phenotype. However, mammalian organisms have developed mechanisms that regulate the expression of some of our genes such that only the maternally-inherited or the paternally-inherited allele will be expressed. As a consequence, the phenotypes controlled by these genes are only dependent on the inheritance of one of the alleles, the other one becoming repressed and irrelevant. These special genes are said to be imprinted, since their differential behavior implies that the DNA must be somehow “labelled” or “imprinted”, in order for the maternal and paternal chromosomes to be recognized and differentially expressed. Since their discovery 60 years ago, research in the field of genomic imprinting has uncovered the location of hundreds of imprinted genes and has advanced our understanding of the mechanisms responsible for “labeling” the maternal and paternally-inherited DNA. These findings support that genomic imprinting depends on the establishment and maintenance of DNA methylation “marks” at critical regulatory elements nearby imprinted genes called imprinting control regions (ICRs). However, the mechanisms responsible for recognizing these “methyl marks” and ultimately promoting parental-specific gene expression/repression are still poorly understood. The goal of our proposal was to investigate the roles of TRIM28 in recognizing methyl marks at imprinting control regions and regulating imprinted gene expression. 

Previous to our research, TRIM28 had been described to behave as a transcriptional regulator that, after being recruited to regulatory sequences in the genome, recruits additional factors that repress gene expression. Amongst many places in the genome, TRIM28 was found to bind the imprinting control regions of most known imprinted clusters and this binding was found to be essential for imprinting control. The analysis of early mouse embryos derived from Trim28 germline-specific mutant mothers, and therefore lacking maternal TRIM28, revealed that TRIM28 is required for maintaining DNA methylation at ICR during the early genome-wide demethylation event that takes place shortly after fertilization to reprogram the genome. These published results were challenged by our finding that hypomorphic Trim28 mutant embryos, which have reduced, albeit not complete loss of TRIM28 function, had imprinting defects similar to those of maternal Trim28 mutants, but did not seem to have any effect on ICR methylation. These initial findings, suggested that TRIM28 was able to control imprinting through a molecular mechanism distinct from the maintenance of DNA methylation at ICRs. Investigating this novel mechanism has been the focus of this research proposal.

Intellectual Merit: By analyzing maternal, zygotic, maternal-zygotic, and conditional Trim28 mutants, we discovered that the transcription factor TRIM28 controls genomic imprinting through distinct mechanisms at different developmental stages. During early genome-wide reprogramming, both maternal and zygotic TRIM28 are required for the maintenance of methylation at germline imprints. However, after genome-wide reprogramming, TRIM28 controls imprinting through alternative mechanisms that involve the transfer of imprints from ICRs to imprinted gene promoters, a process that is poorly understood. During the course of our research, we also discovered that the deletion of the ICR at the Dlk1-Gtl2 imprinted cluster disrupts imprinted gene expression in some embryonic tissues but not others, highlighting the existence of tissue-specific mechanisms of imprinting control. 

Broader Impacts: Our results from the analysis of Trim28 mutants constitute an important contribution to the fields of epigenetics and genomic imprinting since we uncovered novel roles for this transcriptional regulator, as well as mechanistic insight into how this transcription factor controls imprinting at different embryonic stages. Additionally, by highlighting that the ICR at the Dlk1-Gtl2 imprinted cluster has distinct functions in different tissues, our results have uncovered a previously unknown tissue­-specific regulatory control of imprinted gene expression. Together, our studies demonstrate that imprinting control is a much more dynamic process than previously described, with imprinted genes being regulated by different genomic sequences at different tissues and specific embryonic stages. Results have been disseminated to the community through their publication in scientific journals and through seminars and posters at international conferences and local venues. 

The project provided training for several graduate and undergraduate students, as well as support for our participation in several outreach activities for K-12 students, including our annual program on Genetics and Embryonic Development (as part Cornell’s Career Exploration 4H program) and a classroom chemistry activity for 4th graders at the Lansing Elementary School ( “pH in our daily lives”).
